Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Photocatalytic NOx Oxidation and Ion Exchange: New Strategies Towards Functional Corrosion Resistant Concrete Infrastructure

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Reinforced concrete structures exposed to sea water or de-icing salts are susceptible to the corrosion of embedded steel, due to the ingress of chloride ions. Such corrosion results in deterioration, reduces the service-life of structures, and poses a burden to the national economy. In spite of extensive efforts, our current methods of corrosion protection remain either: too expensive, or unable to prevent corrosion actions. This research develops a new strategy that utilizes visible light to decompose air pollutants into chemical agents that can suppress steel corrosion in concrete structures. Such environmentally sustainable solutions are critical to maintain large, widespread and durable infrastructure?a critical driver of economic growth. To support these goals, the research trains a diverse technical workforce at the levels of: post-doctoral scientists, Ph.D. and undergraduate students and high-schoolers at both University of California-Los Angeles and Georgia Tech. Both university groups cross-train with each other, hierarchically and functionally to foster collaboration and exchange scientific advancements needed to preserve infrastructure inventories. The multidisciplinary nature of the work will expose young researchers to cross-cutting intellectual concepts relevant to sustainable development and propelling new technologies to the marketplace.

This research exploits the photoactive behavior of titanium dioxide nanoparticles, and uses visible light, and manipulations of the cement chemistry, to prevent steel corrosion in reinforced concrete. Monosulfate (AFm) phases produced during cement hydration have the ability to intercalate anions in their structure in a preference described as: chloride>nitrate>nitrite>carbonate>sulfate>hydroxide. Thus, cements can be tuned to maximize AFm formation, and capture of chloride species intruding into concrete. Further, up on exposure to light, titanium dioxide can convert atmospheric pollutants in the form of nitrogen oxides to aqueous nitrate/nitrite ions which serve as anodic corrosion inhibitors. When applied in conjunction with each other, these processes work to trap intruding chloride ions within the AFm phase while simultaneously releasing nitrate/nitrite ions (previously stored in the AFm) into the pore solution to ensure steel corrosion inhibition. Towards these objectives this research: (1) synthesizes visible light active titanium dioxide, (2) optimizes cement chemistry to maximize the yield of AFm phases and (3) simulates nitrite/nitrate/chloride transport in concrete to maximize steel corrosion inhibition. The intellectual outcomes of this work include: novel advancements in corrosion inhibition methods which exploit photocatalytic behavior, thermodynamic selectivity and ion exchange preference as a means towards designing regenerative and tunable corrosion protection systems for concrete infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rapid growth of urbanization has negatively affected air quality, posing an immediate threat to human health. As urban and residential areas become more clustered, industrial and traffic related air pollutions have become major concerns. Among these air pollutants, nitrogen oxides (NOx) are considered the most hazardous as they cause a wide variety of health and environmental problems such as impairment of the human respiratory and visual systems and the formation of tropospheric ozone, urban smog and acid rain. To address these problems, this research provides new fundamental insight into the possibility of sequestering nitrogen oxides (NOx) sequestration in cement-based materials, including identification of NOx sequestration pathways and quantification of the NOx uptake capacity based on cement composition. Key intellectual outcomes resulting from this research are detailed and summarized below:

  1. Two prototype photocatalytic reaction chambers (Fig. 1) have been built in this research to study and quantify the photocatalytic NOx uptake and efficiency of different types of cement-based materials. By quantifying their NOx uptake capacities for the first time, engineers and scientists can now estimate the effect of concrete infrastructure on the management of the nitrogen cycle ? one of the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) Grand Challenges.
  2. Four composition of nano-engineered photocatalytic cement-based materials have been examined, including two different methods of introduction nano-titania (TiO2) (i.e.,TiO2-doped and nano TiO2-coated) and two cements (ordinary portland cement and calcium aluminate cement). The results are critical for selecting and designing photocatalytic cement-based materials for different field applications such as building surfaces, pavements, and tunnels. In addition to NOx remediation, the self-cleaning properties of TiO2-coated cement-based materials has been examined, showing promising results for such materials to be used in maintaining concrete infrastructure.
  3. A novel characterization method that combines wet-chemical extraction, UV-vis spectrophotometry, and ion chromatography (Fig. 2 and 3) has been developed to help determine the final products of sequestrated NOx ? nitrite and nitrate ? and quantify their relative abundance. Since nitrite- and nitrate-based corrosion inhibitors are effective in improving corrosion resistance in reinforced concrete, a potential exists to develop ?smart? cement-based photocatalysts, which transform NOx into corrosion inhibitors and benefits the durability of reinforced concrete.
  4. Five individual cement hydration phases have been synthesized in this research to investigate the interaction of NOx with these phases and to understand the roles of these phases in the NOx binding mechanisms and uptake capacity by cement-based materials. The result provides recommendations that hydrated cement-based materials with higher surface areas and rich in aluminate phases are preferable in binding NOx. The information could support engineers and scientists to design such materials through optimizations of physical and chemical properties for enhanced NOx uptake.

In addition to intellectual outcomes, this research has trained multiple undergraduate research assistants through an NSF-funded SENIC Undergraduate Internship in Nanotechnology (SUIN) program: Michael Vanderzwaag from University of Michigan, Ann Arbor in summer of 2016 (Fig. 3), Sarah Hordern from University of Texas, Austin in summer of 2017 (Fig. 4), and Samuel Lucas from Mississippi State University in summer of 2018 (Fig. 5). All of them were able to prepare a comprehensive research report and deliver a well-organized oral presentation at the end of the program. Moreover, this program has also helped enhance their interests in engineering. After their graduation, Michael chose to work as a project engineer at Symbiont after graduation, and Sarah and Samuel chose to continue their research career and enrolled Ph.D. programs at Carnegie Mellon University and Georgia Institute of Technology, respectively.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The rapid growth of urbanization has negatively affected air quality, posing an immediate threat to human health. As urban and residential areas become more clustered, industrial and traffic related air pollutions have become major concerns. Among these air pollutants, nitrogen oxides (NOx) are considered the most hazardous as they cause a wide variety of health and environmental problems such as impairment of the human respiratory and visual systems and the formation of tropospheric ozone, urban smog and acid rain. To address these problems, this research provides new fundamental insight into the possibility of sequestering nitrogen oxides (NOx) sequestration in cement-based materials, including identification of NOx sequestration pathways and quantification of the NOx uptake capacity based on cement composition. Key intellectual outcomes resulting from this research are detailed and summarized below: Two prototype photocatalytic reaction chambers (Fig. 1) have been built in this research to study and quantify the photocatalytic NOx uptake and efficiency of different types of cement-based materials. By quantifying their NOx uptake capacities for the first time, engineers and scientists can now estimate the effect of concrete infrastructure on the management of the nitrogen cycle ? one of the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) Grand Challenges. Four composition of nano-engineered photocatalytic cement-based materials have been examined, including two different methods of introduction nano-titania (TiO2) (i.e.,TiO2-doped and nano TiO2-coated) and two cements (ordinary portland cement and calcium aluminate cement). The results are critical for selecting and designing photocatalytic cement-based materials for different field applications such as building surfaces, pavements, and tunnels. In addition to NOx remediation, the self-cleaning properties of TiO2-coated cement-based materials has been examined, showing promising results for such materials to be used in maintaining concrete infrastructure. A novel characterization method that combines wet-chemical extraction, UV-vis spectrophotometry, and ion chromatography (Fig. 2 and 3) has been developed to help determine the final products of sequestrated NOx ? nitrite and nitrate ? and quantify their relative abundance. Since nitrite- and nitrate-based corrosion inhibitors are effective in improving corrosion resistance in reinforced concrete, a potential exists to develop ?smart? cement-based photocatalysts, which transform NOx into corrosion inhibitors and benefits the durability of reinforced concrete. Five individual cement hydration phases have been synthesized in this research to investigate the interaction of NOx with these phases and to understand the roles of these phases in the NOx binding mechanisms and uptake capacity by cement-based materials. The result provides recommendations that hydrated cement-based materials with higher surface areas and rich in aluminate phases are preferable in binding NOx. The information could support engineers and scientists to design such materials through optimizations of physical and chemical properties for enhanced NOx uptake. In addition to intellectual outcomes, this research has trained multiple undergraduate research assistants through an NSF-funded SENIC Undergraduate Internship in Nanotechnology (SUIN) program: Michael Vanderzwaag from University of Michigan, Ann Arbor in summer of 2016 (Fig. 3), Sarah Hordern from University of Texas, Austin in summer of 2017 (Fig. 4), and Samuel Lucas from Mississippi State University in summer of 2018 (Fig. 5). All of them were able to prepare a comprehensive research report and deliver a well-organized oral presentation at the end of the program. Moreover, this program has also helped enhance their interests in engineering. After their graduation, Michael chose to work as a project engineer at Symbiont after graduation, and Sarah and Samuel chose to continue their research career and enrolled Ph.D. programs at Carnegie Mellon University and Georgia Institute of Technology, respectively.
